newsitem.title: FRANCE: Louis Vuitton optimistic on 97 exports.
newsitem.headline: Louis Vuitton optimistic on 97 exports.

text.p: Luxury travel goods manufacturer Louis Vuitton Malletier said it was optimistic that 1997 exports -- most of which move by air -- will exceed last year's levels.

"We are optimistic on the market outlook for 1997. The strengthening yen and dollar in relation to the French franc can only improve the purchasing power of our major customers," Vuitton's transport manager Bernard Goerens told Reuters.
"During the course of the year Vuitton plans to open several new sales outlets, notably in Dubai and Hanoi, which will boost our air cargo volumes," he added.
The travel goods concern is forecasting a 1996 turnover of 7.7 billion francs compared to 7.4 billion francs in 1995, Goerens said.
Airborne traffic in 1996 totalled 4,362 tonnes compared to 4,448 tonnes in 1995 which was "made up of 156,149 separate shipments compared to 148,711 shipments in 1995," he added

He said: "The 1966 air tonnage was down around two percent on 1995 levels. However, this does not reflect that the fact last year we achieved a significant improvement in load factor per carton on the previous year."
Vuitton's 1996 global shipments -- including airfreight -- to all zones, including France and Europe, totalled 6,500 tonnes, up 8.3 percent on the previous year
Shipments to Vuitton's major export market, Japan, totalled 1,833 tonnes, up 7.3 percent on 1995.

1996 shipments to South-East Asia, comprising 11 countries, totalled 1,333 tonnes, down 4.1 percent while shipments to Hawaii, another key market for Vuitton, totalled 600 tonnes, a decrease of 13.5 percent on the previous year.
Shipments to the U.S. mainland were down four percent on 1995 at 407 tonnes.
The company currently has a retail network totalling 203 boutiques worldwide.
Vuitton's parent company LVMH recently gained control of U.S. group, Duty Free Shoppers (DFS), which has a network of 180 boutiques mainly in the Asia-Pacific zone.
